body:
We already got dropped by one service so far. And the minute we have any sort of growth to the point where we may threaten big tech they'll squash us like a bug.

That attitude is incredibly shortsighted and if we adopt it, they'll take the site from us so fast we won't even know what happened.

body:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. 
Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.
body_html:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. body:
I don’t see ruqqus as conservative alt media, but they do. The fact that we have conservatives here makes us a target. I’m liberal but we absolutely need to protect conservative voices and places free of censorship. 

On this, there can be no compromise from the left. We can’t weedle and whine and pretend censorship is okay as long as it’s not us. We should have stood up for others long ago. Instead, we silenced them. An embarrassment.

parent.body:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. 
Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.
parent.body_html:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.

body:
It could be hosted in a basement, there might be reliability problems, and networking may be a bit of a challenge, good luck finding an IP transit provider willing to run a dedicated fiber connection to your home. It's much easier to go directly through a datacenter. 

Professional datacenters rarely care about the content hosted in their facilities, as long as it's not illegal. Because all they're doing is providing housing and utilities for your equipment, and usually the internet connection(s) are separate from the data center administration. You also don't have to disclose where exactly it's being hosted, and if you're using your own IP addresses (or are using a CDN like Cloudflare), they won't be able to find out either. 
Floatplane, a subscription video service from Linus Tech Tips, has a similar setup. We don't know where exactly it's being hosted. All we know is it's in Canada.

You also don't have to disclose where exactly it's being hosted, and if you're using your own IP addresses (or are using a CDN like Cloudflare), they won't be able to find out either. parent.body:
It could be hosted in a basement, there might be reliability problems, and networking may be a bit of a challenge, good luck finding an IP transit provider willing to run a dedicated fiber connection to your home. It's much easier to go directly through a datacenter. 

Professional datacenters rarely care about the content hosted in their facilities, as long as it's not illegal. Because all they're doing is providing housing and utilities for your equipment, and usually the internet connection(s) are separate from the data center administration. You also don't have to disclose where exactly it's being hosted, and if you're using your own IP addresses (or are using a CDN like Cloudflare), they won't be able to find out either. 
Floatplane, a subscription video service from Linus Tech Tips, has a similar setup. We don't know where exactly it's being hosted. All we know is it's in Canada.

parent.body:
> Basically, once you are bare metal, you can no longer be canceled by big tech.

Not so fast. They will demand that upstream providers, Internet exchanges, DNS registrars, data centers and other infrastructure providers don't do business with companies run by conservatives. Also, who owns TLD .com? DoC, i.e. US government. Don't let your guard down just because you may move to bare metal.

parent.body:
It could be hosted in a basement, there might be reliability problems, and networking may be a bit of a challenge, good luck finding an IP transit provider willing to run a dedicated fiber connection to your home. It's much easier to go directly through a datacenter. 

Professional datacenters rarely care about the content hosted in their facilities, as long as it's not illegal. Because all they're doing is providing housing and utilities for your equipment, and usually the internet connection(s) are separate from the data center administration. You also don't have to disclose where exactly it's being hosted, and if you're using your own IP addresses (or are using a CDN like Cloudflare), they won't be able to find out either. 
Floatplane, a subscription video service from Linus Tech Tips, has a similar setup. We don't know where exactly it's being hosted. All we know is it's in Canada.

You also don't have to disclose where exactly it's being hosted, and if you're using your own IP addresses (or are using a CDN like Cloudflare), they won't be able to find out either. Floatplane, a subscription video service from Linus Tech Tips, has a similar setup. We don't know where exactly it's being hosted. All we know is it's in Canada.

body: The way that Git works, is that everybody who has cloned the repo will have a complete copy of the entire history of the code at that point in time, and it's trivially easy to host your own repos (about 1 minute to set it up for anyone that knows Unix - it doesn't even require any special server software). Git as such is rather censorship-resistant. The other stuff that GitHub adds on top of it (issues, pull requests, etc)...less so. But it's not like there's going to be a big "oh shit" moment if GitHub kicks Ruqqus off their platform.

body:
If your domain is AWS get that moved ASAP, before anything else. The rest of the infrastructure can be recreated but if they take the domain it's going to be really hard for some to find this place again. (Edit: nevermind looks like you use Epik, good)

I would have a plan to toss up a quick status page if they take you down, maybe with links to a chat space. I suggest Nearlyfreespeech.net for this use. IMHO they are a little too expensive for hosting high-traffic dynamic sites, but they are good for static pages like this.

Edit 2: see https://www.nearlyfreespeech.net/help/abuse for why I recommend them.

parent.body:
If your domain is AWS get that moved ASAP, before anything else. The rest of the infrastructure can be recreated but if they take the domain it's going to be really hard for some to find this place again. (Edit: nevermind looks like you use Epik, good)

I would have a plan to toss up a quick status page if they take you down, maybe with links to a chat space. I suggest Nearlyfreespeech.net for this use. IMHO they are a little too expensive for hosting high-traffic dynamic sites, but they are good for static pages like this.

Edit 2: see https://www.nearlyfreespeech.net/help/abuse for why I recommend them.

No, I mean a backup website for contacting users. You can just DNS redirect to a status page somewhere.

Else you get completely shut off from users if system is taken down.

Maybe even have that one do some sort of scheduled ping/canary thing. A one liner cronjob. This is supported by most cheap webhosting services. If the main site is down for more than X minutes display some info.

post.title: Ruqqus needs to get.off of Amazon Web Service and they need to do it yesterday.

body:
These are people who have literally never lived in the real world, worked a real job, or had any sort of real relationships with other men or women; a veritable army of mid-20 year old neckbearded autists who spend all their time on reddit and video games when they're not coding/programming (the only useful work they know how to do). 

And they are coming for us.

It is not enough for them to completely silence and remove opposing viewpoints from *their* part of the internet. I am in a Discord group with a bunch of people who don't know that I am a centrist. They openly discuss, in highly technical terms, how to eliminate disagreeable voices from the internet entirely. They *NEED* to hunt down and silence all opposition. This is not going to get better.  We are going to constantly have to be one step ahead of them and need to move **quickly** to make our communication impervious to constant attack. Eventually, because time is on their side, they are going to figure out how to completely blockade free speech on the internet at one of the many chokepoints at which traffic has to pass through. We need to be thinking long term to our ultimate places of refuge, our Taiwan, our 38th parallel. The solution is the "Dark Web." Encrypted, P2P, decentralized is the only way this is going to work long term. The big trick is how do you make it stupidly simple for person of average intelligence to be able to use such a service easily? That's the job. That's what has to happen.

parent.body:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. 
Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.

parent.body:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. 
Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.

parent.body: Internet exchanges are a weak point. Should someone accomplish to pressure major IXs into filtering content by ASN then it's effectively like erasing it from the Internet for huge portions of the Internet. Changing DCs, ISPs, TLDs or IP space would do nothing, you would need a new ASN or ride someone else's but then the circle repeats itself.
parent.body_html: Internet exchanges are a weak point. Should someone accomplish to pressure major IXs into filtering content by ASN then it's effectively like erasing it from the Internet for huge portions of the Internet. Changing DCs, ISPs, TLDs or IP space would do nothing, you would need a new ASN or ride someone else's but then the circle repeats itself.

parent.body:
They will probably go after the Domain Name next, so it might be good to have some alt domains on multiple TLDs. It would be super helpful if we could create a communication network to share these domains in case a popular one gets compromised.

Also they might go after the GitHub repo as well soon, so getting mirrors for that would be good.

They will probably go after the Domain Name next, so it might be good to have some alt domains on multiple TLDs. It would be super helpful if we could create a communication network to share these domains in case a popular one gets compromised.

Also they might go after the GitHub repo as well soon, so getting mirrors for that would be good.

parent.body:
Seriously consider looking into mini PC clusters and using a suite like Openstack, you'll get a better bang for your buck. 
Instead of having to cram 5 physical servers into a 24U rack, you could have 20 NUCs per each 2U worth of rack space, giving you a 100 node cluster in a half-rack environment.

I've mentioned this before but it would also be worthwhile for Ruqqus to acquire IP space (v6 but also v4 if possible), and an AS number, then peer with multiple upstream bandwidth providers. If one decides to deplatform Ruqqus, it doesn't take the whole site down, it just removes their path to Ruqqus.

body:
"Bare metal" doesn't usually just imply physical hardware. After all, ALL software runs on physical hardware at some layer. "Bare metal" typically implies running something without virtualization or containerization directly on the hardware as either an embedded system, or an application on an operating system.

In the world of virtual machines, containers/orchestration, this doesn't make much sense to do anymore. I'm guessing he means not using shared hardware/cloud providers or a VPS, which just means you own your own hardware, but I wouldn't personally call this "bare metal".
body_html:
"Bare metal" doesn't usually just imply physical hardware. After all, ALL software runs on physical hardware at some layer. "Bare metal" typically implies running something without virtualization or containerization directly on the hardware as either an embedded system, or an application on an operating system.

In the world of virtual machines, containers/orchestration, this doesn't make much sense to do anymore. I'm guessing he means not using shared hardware/cloud providers or a VPS, which just means you own your own hardware, but I wouldn't personally call this "bare metal".

💻 No promotion of other sites that aren't a fork of Ruqqus

🟪 Ruqqus-related only. This is a community dedicated to Ruqqus meta discussion. Content may involve technology and politics but must have ample context in Ruqqus.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

For press releases, visit +RuqqusPress.

For updates and patch notes, visit +changelog.

For ideas and feedback, visit +BetaFeedback

For bug reports, visit +RuqqusBugs
